title: A Multidomain Intervention Program for Older People With Dementia: A Pilot Study
description_brief: This is a pilot study to assess the feasibility of a multidomain intervention for older people with dementia in nursing homes. Participants will be randomized into two equal groups, to receive either an intensive multidomain intervention (intervention group) or regular health advice (control group). The intervention will include physical, cognitive, and social interventions and management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. We hypothesize that the multidomain intervention will be feasible in Vietnam, and participants who receive the intervention will show improvement in cognitive function, quality of life, behaviors, functional ability, sleep, and in reduction of falls, and death rate compared to those in the control group during the 6 months intervention period
description_detailed:
This is a two-armed, multicenter, randomized controlled pilot study, based in 3 nursing homes in Hanoi, Vietnam.

The study PI and/or researchers in the research team will contact adults aged 60 years and older in the nursing homes to introduce the study. If they are interested in participating, the study PI and/or researchers in the research team will screen them for their eligibility. If they meet the inclusion criteria and are interested in participating, written informed consent will be obtained.

Participants who agreed to participate in the study will be randomized into two equal groups, to receive either an intensive multidomain intervention (intervention group) or regular health advice (control group).

Participants in both the intervention and the control groups will be treated for dementia according to the recommendations of the Vietnam Alzheimer's Disease and Neurocognitive Disorders Association.

All participants will meet the study physician to have an examination at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. At each examination, participants will undergo a physical examination, anthropometry (weight, hip and waist circumference), blood pressure determination, pulse rate and rhythm, risks of cardiovascular and metabolic diseases (smoking, drinking, hypertension, coronary artery disease, dyslipidemia, atherosclerosis, diabetes) and assess blood test results (lipid profile, HbA1C, and fasting glucose if patients have diabetes). Results will be provided to participants and their doctors.

In addition to what is given to both groups, participants in the intervention group will receive four intervention components: (1) physical activity intervention; (2) cognitive intervention; (3) social intervention; and (4) management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. Physical activity and cognitive stimulation interventions will be performed at separate sessions.

All outcome measures will be administered at baseline, 6 months

groups.title: Intervention Group
groups.description:
The multidomain intervention comprised: (1) physical activity; (2) cognitive intervention; (3) social intervention; and (4) management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. Physical activity and cognitive stimulation sessions were conducted separately, each held twice a week. Social intervention was integrated into the physical and cognitive intervention sessions.

For the management of metabolic and vascular risk factors, participants received education on the importance of minimizing these risks, guidance on adopting healthier lifestyles, and treatment recommendations when necessary, provided by cardiologists and endocrinologists.

groups.title: Control Group
groups.description: The control group will receive general health advice every 3 months based on their physical examination and blood results. They will be provided information on the vascular risk factors for dementia and will receive instruction and handouts on diet and exercise.

groups.title: Intervention Group
groups.description: Multidomain intervention included: (1) physical activity; (2) cognitive intervention; and (3) social intervention as well as (4) management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. Physical activity and cognitive stimulation interventions will be performed at separate sessions

outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Adherence was only assessed for the intervention group

outcomeMeasures.title: Global Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description: Global cognition will be measured by Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive (ADAS-Cog); score ranging from 0-70, a higher score indicates worse impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

outcomeMeasures.title: Executive Function Via Clock Drawing Test
outcomeMeasures.description: Excutive function will be assessed using Clock drawing test. Scores range from 0-10, with lower scores indicating greater cognitive impairment
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

outcomeMeasures.title: Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of Dementia (BPSD)
outcomeMeasures.description: Behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) will be measured using the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) questionnaire. The total NPI score ranging from 0 to 144 points. Higher scores indicate greater severity of BPSD
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

outcomeMeasures.title: Total Dependence of Participants Assessed Using the Barthel Index
outcomeMeasures.description: Total dependence will be assessed using the Barthel Index, with a total score of 100, where scores between 0 and 20 indicate total dependence.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

outcomeMeasures.description: Quality of sleep will be assessed using Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. A global PSQI score greater than 5 distinguishing good and poor sleepers
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

groups.title: Intervention Group

outcomeMeasures.title: Health-related Quality of Life
outcomeMeasures.description: Health-related quality of life will be assessed using the Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease scale. The Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease scale measures the overall quality of life in individuals with Alzheimer's disease. It consists of 13 items, each rated on a 4-point Likert scale. The total score is obtained by summing the scores of all 13 items, resulting in a possible range from 13 to 52 points. Higher scores indicate a better quality of life.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

outcomeMeasures.title: Death
outcomeMeasures.description: Death will be assessed through reports from care staff, nursing home records.

outcomeMeasures.title: Functional Ability Via the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional ability will be assessed using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale. A summary score ranges from 0 (low function, dependent) to 8 (high function, independent) for women, and 0 through 5 for men.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

groups.title: Intervention Group
groups.description: Multidomain intervention included: (1) physical activity; (2) cognitive intervention; and (3) social intervention as well as (4) management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. Physical activity and cognitive stimulation interventions will be performed at separate sessions

groups.title: Control Group
groups.description: The control group will receive general health advice every 3 months based on their physical examination and blood results. They will be provided information on the vascular risk factors for dementia and will receive instruction and handouts on diet and exercise.

outcomeMeasures.title: Dependence of Participants Assessed Using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Dependence will be assessed using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living scale, which evaluates the ability to perform eight daily tasks, including using the telephone, shopping, meal preparation, housekeeping, laundry, transportation, medication management, and financial management. The total score ranges from 0 to 8, with 8 indicating full independence and scores below 8 suggesting dependence in functional activities.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were analyzed on an intention-to-treat

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: For each participant, adverse events were collected for the duration of participation in the study (up to 6 months)

eventGroups.title: Intervention Group
eventGroups.description: Multidomain intervention included: (1) physical activity; (2) cognitive intervention; and (3) social intervention as well as (4) management of metabolic and vascular risk factors. Physical activity and cognitive stimulation interventions will be performed at separate sessions

eventGroups.title: Control Group
eventGroups.description: The control group will receive general health advice every 3 months based on their physical examination and blood results. They will be provided information on the vascular risk factors for dementia and will receive instruction and handouts on diet and exercise.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests a non‑pharmacologic, multidomain program (physical activity, cognitive stimulation, social interventions, and management of metabolic/vascular risk factors) intended primarily to improve cognitive function (also quality of life, behaviour, function, sleep, and reduce falls/death). This is an intervention to enhance cognition and related outcomes rather than a biologic or small‑molecule that targets Alzheimer pathology. citeturn0search0turn0search4

Act: Key extracted details — intervention components: physical exercise, Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (group cognitive sessions), social activities, and vascular/metabolic risk management; study type: randomized pilot in nursing homes (Vietnam); no drug or biologic is used. Because the primary intended effect is cognitive and functional improvement through behavioural/rehabilitative means (not disease‑modifying pharmaceutical action), the best matching category is 'cognitive enhancer'. Sources confirming the protocol and intervention details: the published study protocol and trial registry. citeturn0search0turn0search5

Reflect: The classification aligns with the category definitions: it is not a biologic (no antibody/vaccine) nor a small molecule; it is an interventional program aimed at improving cognition and related symptoms (so 'cognitive enhancer' is the closest fit). Note: secondary aims include reducing neuropsychiatric symptoms and improving behaviour/quality of life, so some outcomes overlap with 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement', but the central target described is cognitive/function enhancement via multidomain non‑drug measures. Trial sources used for verification are cited above. citeturn0search0turn0search4
explanation_agent: Reason: The described trial tests a non‑pharmacologic, multidomain intervention (physical activity, cognitive stimulation, social activities, and vascular/metabolic risk management) intended to improve cognition and related outcomes rather than administering a drug, biologic, or molecule that acts on a defined biological pathway (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation). CADRO categories are focused on biological targets; this intervention does not specify a molecular or cellular target.

Act: Extracted details — no drug or biologic is used (trial drug: []); intervention components are behavioral/rehabilitative (exercise, Cognitive Stimulation Therapy, social interventions, risk‑factor management). Because there is no identifiable pharmacologic target or pathway, the trial does not fit the CADRO therapeutic categories that map to molecular/pathophysiologic targets. Per instructions, non‑therapeutic or non‑targeted interventions should be classified as 'T) Other'.

Reflect: The classification 'T) Other' fits the CADRO guidance for interventions that are not directed at a biological target (or where no drug/target is present). If a pharmacologic agent or biologic had been part of the program (with an identifiable mechanism—e.g., amyloid antibody, anti‑inflammatory drug, cholinesterase inhibitor), a different CADRO category would be appropriate. No web search was performed because no drug or target gene/pathway was provided or implied in the trial description.
